quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 11 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 11.9: Indicators
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Selection, mechanism, and endpoint of acid-base indicators

questions.question: An acid-base indicator is chemically defined as:
options: A weak organic acid or base whose conjugate forms have different colors.
A strong acid that reacts with the analyte.
An inert dye that changes color based on temperature.
A metal catalyst that speeds up neutralization.
questions.explanation: Indicators are weak acids ($HIn$). When they lose a proton to become $In^{-}$, the electronic structure changes, resulting in a different absorbed wavelength of light.

questions.question: The 'end point' of a titration is the point where:
options: The moles of acid exactly equal the moles of base.
questions.explanation: The end point is an experimental observation (color change), whereas the equivalence point is a theoretical stoichiometric requirement.

questions.question: For a titration to be accurate, the indicator should be chosen such that its $pK_{a}$ is:
options: Close to the pH at the equivalence point.
As far from the equivalence point as possible.
Equal to the pKa of the analyte acid.
questions.explanation: Indicators change color over a range of approximately $pK_{In} \pm 1$. To minimize titration error, this range must overlap with the steep vertical section of the titration curve.

questions.question: Which indicator would be most appropriate for a strong acid-strong base titration (equivalence point pH = 7)?
questions.explanation: Bromothymol blue is ideal because its transition range surrounds the neutral equivalence point of 7.

questions.question: Why is phenolphthalein often used for weak acid-strong base titrations?
options: The equivalence point occurs at a basic pH (above 7).
It reacts with the weak acid to make it stronger.
It is the only indicator that is colorless.
questions.explanation: Weak acid-strong base titrations have a basic equivalence point due to conjugate base hydrolysis; phenolphthalein's range (8.2–10) matches this.

questions.question: In a highly acidic solution, what is the dominant form of the indicator $HIn \rightleftharpoons H^{+} + In^{-}$?
options: The solution remains colorless regardless of the indicator.
questions.explanation: According to Le Chatelier's Principle, high $[H^{+}]$ shifts the equilibrium to the left, favoring the protonated acid form ($HIn$).

questions.question: What is the typical pH range over which an indicator changes color?
questions.explanation: The human eye typically perceives a color change when the ratio of the two forms changes from 1:10 to 10:1, which spans roughly 2 pH units.

questions.question: If methyl orange (range 3.1–4.4) is used for a weak acid-strong base titration, the titration will end:
questions.explanation: Since the equivalence point for a weak acid is basic (>7) and methyl orange changes color at an acidic pH, the color change will occur long before enough base has been added.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding a 'universal indicator'?
options: It is a mixture of several different indicators.
It only works for strong acids.
It cannot be used in aqueous solutions.
questions.explanation: Universal indicators combine multiple indicators to provide a continuous spectrum of colors across a wide pH range (typically 1–14).

questions.question: Which indicator would be best for titrating $NH_{3}$ with $HCl$ (equivalence point pH $\approx$ 5)?
questions.explanation: A weak base titrated with a strong acid results in an acidic equivalence point. Methyl red's range (4.2–6.2) is the best fit.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a perfect eye for indicator selection.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember the difference between end point and equivalence point.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review how $pK_{a}$ determines the useful range.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on matching the indicator range to the equivalence point pH.
